**Jean Hamel**

Jean Hamel is a Canadian professional ice hockey defenceman who has played in the National Hockey League (NHL). **Early Life and Career**

Hamel was born on June 6, 1952, in Asbestos, Quebec, Canada. He began his junior hockey career with the Drummondville Rangers of the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League (QMJHL) in 1969. During his time with the Rangers, Hamel was drafted by the St. Louis Blues in the 3rd round (31st overall) of the 1972 NHL Amateur Draft. **National Hockey League Career**

Hamel made his NHL debut with the St. Louis Blues during the 1972-73 season. He played for the Blues until 1979, when he was traded to the Quebec Nordiques. Hamel spent four seasons with the Nordiques before being traded to the Detroit Red Wings in 1983. He played for the Red Wings until 1985, when he retired from professional hockey. **NHL Statistics**

Throughout his 12-year NHL career, Hamel played in 699 games, scoring 26 goals and 135 assists for a total of 161 points. He also accumulated 766 penalty minutes. **Sources**

* "Jean Hamel". Hockey-Reference.com. Retrieved 2023-02-20. * "Jean Hamel". Eliteprospects.com. Retrieved 2023-02-20. * "1972 NHL Amateur Draft". Hockey-Reference.com. Retrieved 2023-02-20. * "St. Louis Blues All-Time Roster". St. Louis Blues. Retrieved 2023-02-20. * "Quebec Nordiques All-Time Roster". Quebec Nordiques. Retrieved 2023-02-20. * "Detroit Red Wings All-Time Roster". Detroit Red Wings. Retrieved 2023-02-20. This Wikipedia entry provides comprehensive evidence that Jean Hamel played in the National Hockey League (NHL) by presenting his early life and career, NHL career, and NHL statistics.
content.source_2:
**COLLEGE HOOPS STAR JEAN HAMEL SHINES IN NCAA DIVISION I**

In the world of college basketball, few players have made a splash as significant as Jean Hamel, the talented forward dominating the court in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. As the season heats up, Hamel's impressive stats and clutch performances have earned him a reputation as one of the most exciting young players in the country. Hamel, a junior at the University of Michigan, has been a force to be reckoned with, leading his team to a 10-2 record in the Big Ten Conference. His impressive 22.5 points per game average has him ranked third in the league, and his 7.8 rebounds per game have coaches and scouts alike taking notice. "Jean has been a game-changer for us," said Michigan head coach, John Beilein. "His work ethic is unmatched, and his ability to score from anywhere on the court has been a huge asset for our team." Hamel's rise to stardom hasn't gone unnoticed by his peers. "Jean is a nightmare to defend," said Ohio State guard, CJ Jackson. "He's got the size, the speed, and the skills to take over a game at any moment. We've had to game plan specifically for him, and even then, he still finds ways to get buckets." The NCAA Division I men's basketball league, comprised of 358 teams from across the country, is one of the most competitive collegiate sports leagues in the world. Hamel's success in this arena is a testament to his hard work and dedication. According to data from the NCAA, Hamel's scoring average is among the top 10 in the country, and his rebounding average ranks him in the top 20. His impressive stats have also earned him a spot on the Wooden Award watch list, given annually to the nation's top college basketball player. As the season enters its final stretch, Hamel and his Michigan teammates are poised to make a deep run in the NCAA Tournament. With his sights set on a national championship, Hamel remains focused on the task at hand. "I'm just trying to help my team win games," Hamel said in a recent interview. "If I can do that, the individual accolades will take care of themselves. We've got a great team, and I'm excited to see what we can accomplish."
